comment: perfect thank you

00:00- 2:17 Genomic library  After that, cDNA library.  Summary:   Genomic library includes the whole genome (not a surprise, since the name is genomic), which is cut in smaller pieces and integrated in bunch of bacteria via plasmide (vector).   cDNA- includes only parts of a genome which transcribe proteins. First steps- to take a mRNA, which is transformed to cDNA with enzyme reverse transcriptase and then surround each of it with restriction fragments in order to safeguard it until it's integrated with plasmid.   Genome library- the whole genome cDNA library- parts of the genome which transcribe proteins

ANAS Said ايوة طبعا كلام حضرتك صح .. بس الخطوة دي الدكتور اعتبرها included يعني جوا الشرح .. 1- reverse transcriptase converts mRNA to cDNA  2-DNA polymerase is used to create double strands cDNA 3-restriction sites are added to the ends of dcDNA to prevent distortion of the wanted genes  4-restriction enzymes are used , on both plasmid and DNA ...  5- insertion occurs .. thus the cloning proceeds as the first one

Sorry, I'm still a tad bit confused.  It is possible for a plasmid to reanneal.   So Some of the cut up DNA would not be legated on to a vector. So already some genes won't be included into the genomic library.  Secondly, The probability that any one plasmid is successfully entered in any one cell is as low as 0.1%, so a GREAT amount of vectors with all the other DNA inserts will not enter the bacterial cell.  Therefore a great amount of pieces of the original genome won't be included in library

Just to add, in contrast to conventional filamentous phage vehicles, lambda phage offers unique advantages. Particularly, lambda phage represents a feasible choice for constructing complex genome libraries because of its simple structure and flexible DNA. Reference: http://www.creative-biolabs.com/genome-library-construction-service-via-lambda-phage.html
